Output Indicator 2.2. Number of views of website’s content on social media platforms.

actual.value: 2’154 new followers joined UPR Info’s twitter account and there was an increase of 23% among the Facebook followers. In 2019. UPR Info also launched its profile on Instagram to reach out and engage a younger public in the human rights mechanisms.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 1.1. Number of UPR stakeholders trained on the UPR process.
Output Indicator 1.1. Number of UPR stakeholders trained on the UPR process.

actual.value: During the reporting period. UPR Info organized and delivered trainings sessions organized by other international organizations and NGOs in Geneva. In 2018 UPR Info delivered 31 training sessions. approximately 500 among CSOs members. HRDs. diplomats. members of government and international organizations. students and professors were better equipped with necessary knowledge on how to engage with the UPR in Geneva. Up to July 2019. UPR Info delivered 21 training sessions and 468 among CSOs members. HRDs. diplomats. members of government and international organizations. students and professors were better equipped with necessary knowledge on how to engage with the UPR.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 2.3. Number of interventions undertaken at Item 6 General Debate to bring important issues to the attention of the HRC.
Output Indicator 2.3. Number of interventions undertaken at Item 6 General Debate to bring important issues to the attention of the HRC.

actual.value: Since 2018 UPR Info delivered 6 statements at the Human Rights Council (HRC) under General Debate Item 6. These statements called for participation. inclusiveness. and accountability of all national stakeholders in the UPR process to ensure effective follow-up and implementation of the UPR recommendations. UPR Info also invited States to establish National Mechanisms for Reporting and Follow-up (NMRFs). including comprehensive human rights action plans containing baseline and target indicators. In addition. UPR Info encouraged States to establish human rights committee within Parliaments and to involve them in the NMRFs.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 3.2. Nature of feedback on the practical tools produced by the end of the project and number of recipients.
Output Indicator 3.2. Nature of feedback on the practical tools produced by the end of the project and number of recipients.

actual.value: UPR Info Database and website is recognized by all stakeholders as a great tool to receive first-hand information. According to a survey in September 2018. 83% of the visitors uses the website for the database of recommendations. followed by 63% of the audience who uses the website for the Pre-sessions Programme and 52% for UN Documents. According to the results extracted. 80% of the respondents’ rate with “very well” or “good” the following features of the website: News. Database of recommendations. Research Reports and Publications and Pre-Session Programme page.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 3.1. Number of practical tools produced and number of recipients (electronical or physical of copies by the end of the project).
Output Indicator 3.1. Number of practical tools produced and number of recipients (electronical or physical of copies by the end of the project).

actual.value: UPR Info developed an online a series of curricula for webinars which had a wider outreach to civil society in countries that otherwise would have not had access to guidance for their engagement in the UPR. 8 online sessions were delivered on optimising the Stakeholders’ Reports to the UPR and on improving the implementation of UPR recommendations through Mid-term Reporting. The recording of the online webinar has been distributed to 280 members of the civil society. including HRDs and NHRIs. UPR Info has also developed a new curriculum on HR monitoring for the UPR to support NHRIs. civil society and State members. to identify contextually relevant indicators and benchmarks for implementing and measuring HR at country level. The curriculum was delivered in Cambodia. Jordan. Ivory Coast. DRC and during a regional seminar for NHRIs in Asia.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 2.1. Number of news articles, factsheets and newsletters produced and disseminated through UPR Info’s website.
Output Indicator 2.1. Number of news articles, factsheets and newsletters produced and disseminated through UPR Info’s website.

actual.value: UPR Info has published on its website ca. 60 news about the UPR. including highlights on Item 6 of the HRC sessions. key procedural information (e.g deadlines. communications from the OHCHR). highlights on the UPR sessions and UPR Info activities. In December 2018. UPR Info has developed factsheets for NHRIs and Parliamentarians that were distributed in Uganda and Belgium. UPR Info distributed 15 campaigns to its audience through mailchimp.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 1.2. Feedback of trained UPR stakeholders.
Output Indicator 1.2. Feedback of trained UPR stakeholders.

actual.value: UPR Info received positive feedback from the participants to the training sessions.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 3.3. Regular updates of the database with recommendations and improved features and categorizations for the users.
Output Indicator 3.3. Regular updates of the database with recommendations and improved features and categorizations for the users.

actual.value: UPR Info’s database has been updated with more than 8000 recommendations. In 2019. UPR Info has worked on a new version of the database to improve its capacities. Among the new features introduced in the updating of UPR Info’s website. there is the possibility to import data from State’s reports directly on our database in two languages (English and French). expanding the accessibility of the tool to monitor the implementation of UPR recommendations. Positive feedback has been received by UPR Info from stakeholders using the database.
